comments.commentBody:
'...the relationship is usually consensual but the power imbalance means it will never be equal and that is where the harm lurks...'

No relationships are ever completely 'equal' and it appears that she was the one who 'used' him.

'...Initally rape meant a woman who was attacked by stranger and is forced to have sex...'

Incorrect. It does not have to be a 'stranger', just that force without consent is used.

And no, begging and pleading is not 'force'.

Dear RKPT,
What a beautiful post. You have made me cry but in the sweetest way possible. As one poster said above, it felt like his youth died when he learned this news. But no matter how old or feeble we Boomers & just pre-Boomers get, we'll always know we had the best music to grow up with! Rock on, Lesley Gore! You GO, girl!

I am sad when a person who provided so much joy leaves us. Though in the case of a musician, I am happy knowing they left behind millions of fans and great sounds that will last forever.

I grew up blasting Leslie's sounds through a little transistor radio I was lucky enough to own. I loved my radio almost as much as my family's B&W 13' Motorola that allowed me to watch Ms. Gore's performances.

Never followed her career, though learning that she was happy with one partner for most of her adult life made me smile. Leslie deserved happiness after sharing so much love with her fans.

Thank you Leslie Gore for all the smiles.
I loved all her songs when I was a young girl. Even now if one of her songs comes on the radio, I remember every word to every song! RIP MS. Gore

"Gore was the reductio ad absurdum of the sheer vapidity of pop music."

You might, Fred White, want to save your snark and lack of class -- do you always disgorge your bile at the wrong times? -- for your friends.
Her amazing voice marked an era and my heart. What a wonderful woman and what a storyteller.

her brother's 2 Oscars were for writing the music for "Fame"...best song and
best original score...and his name is not David, it's Michael

I turned 12 in 1963 and just spontaneously started listening to a tiny transistor radio turned low every night as I drifted off.  Music suddenly mattered.  Seventh grade, especially in the early '60's, was the dividing line between kid and teen, some kids in my class started dating (at 12!), and the social implications of someone wearing someone's ring were beyond huge.  We were all so sweetly self-centered, figuring out where we stood in in our brave new teen world.  Lesley was such a big part of my intro to that world.  She captured the feeling of being a young teen better than anyone, and as the years rolled on those songs were still there to help us remember the beautiful drama of our young lives.  Thank you so much Lesley.

I remember that the first time I saw her or heard her music was on that Batman episode referenced in the obituary. Oh, gosh, I so wanted to be her (especially because of Pink Pussycat's romance with Burt Ward--such a cutie!). So I fell in love with her music, and bought the album where she sang "California Nights." Even now it is on my iPod, and I'm 58. I love when I hear the other songs on the oldies channel, but California nights always brings me back to my childhood and pre-teens (watched Batman in re-runs), and that two-part episode where she sings "California Nights." It is a fond memory.
R.I.P. Jersey Girl.

Every song of hers was my absolute favorite!  And each one still takes me back to a particular day/place/event - her songs were that evocative.  It was pop and it was light, but it was oh so good.  Her Greatest Hits album inexplicably remained for decades in an honored place in my vinyl collection, to the horror of my friends, and then my wife.  And guess which one had the most pops and hisses from being played to death!  BDE, Lesley; you gave a lot of happiness to this Bronx boy.....
NM, I suggest that a lot of medical personnel don't even see patients as an ID number, but rather see them as "the diabetes", the "appendectomy", etc.

Physicians can succeed by stepping out of themselves and imagining roles reversed: what if I, or my parents, or my spouse, were the patient?  How would a Doctor earn my trust and confidence?  What would make me feel respected and cared for?  What would help me understand what living with a diagnosis means?  Does the MD hear me out about what I've gone through before telling me about research studies?  What would make being an inpatient tolerable and help recovery?   Am I seen as a person rather than a patient ID number?  I think that identifying with those they treat would help improve care quality.

As for being discharged....I actually waved a $10. bill around at the nurses' station trying to get one of them to remove the IV line so I could go home. The reason I was told I couldn't leave was because "the IV line is still in". I watched carefully as it was finally withdrawn. Now I know how to do it. Watch me flee on my own next time rather than wait around.
I was told by the nurse that if I checked myself out insurance would not pay for my stay....so I folded. Next time I'm walking out even if I have to pull out my own IV.
Except if you delivered a baby 25 hours ago, then they can't wait to throw you out the door, carrying a infant starving because your milk hasn't come in yet, and you're bleeding and all doped up.

A little bit of indifference causes a lot of suffering. In dealing with my aging parents' health issues I found that one caring person does make a difference. And boy oh boy, NOBODY can get a good night's rest in the hospital (I'll leave it unnamed but it was in La Jolla, California.)  My father insisted on going home as early as he could (in his late 60s, in for a surgery, 2-3 night stay that he shortened to 1 night) simply because he knew that the lack of sleep was more detrimental to his recovery than anything else. Also, MY GOODNESS, have you ever tried to be DISCHARGED from a hospital? So many people apparently need to sign off that the process is super slow and always getting stuck.  Both my parents and my husband spent most of the day they were supposed to be released simply waiting ... and waiting... and waiting...  because someone somewhere couldn't Dr. X to sign a form. My father was told around 6am he'd be leaving. We were actually allowed to leave around 3:30pm. It was hard to even get any lunch since food service stopped (because, duh, he was being discharged) and I was afraid to leave his room to go get food. I harassed nurses, I phoned... Nothing happened. So, that was a day of exhausting waiting where my dad missed a meal while trying to recover from major surgery and not a single person at this La Jolla, Calif. hospital even noticed or apologized!
Never? George W Bush launched a crackdown of illegal workers that was blocked by a federal judge in 2007. The opposite side also called him an activist judge at the time. You should read more.
Every illegal that becomes legal, is a potential Democrat. That is the end game for Obama. Sadly it all boils down to politics and not to keeping families together.

The Federal Courts must decide this matter, not the Speaker of the House, who seems intent punishing the American people for what the Speaker seems to think are Obama's sin.

The most charitable thing one can say about the ruling is that the Jidge has made an excellent case for the proposition that white presidents have more powers than black ones, given the Reagan Bush precedents.

The least charitable, that the judge is a bigot, evidenced by his remarks during argument to the effect that Hispanics are the "worst" criminals. How else interpret his fears about the people Obama is unleashing on society?

I support President Obama's executive order on immigration. The GOP simply wants to prevent millions of Hispanics from getting citizenship because if they do they are likely to vote Democrat, and this assault against the President's legitimate lawful authority is just an extension of the voter suppression as well as more "get Obama to get Obama" nonsense. If they had done something constructive and addressed the immigration issue this wouldn't even be happening.  The GOP needs to be willing to negotiate and compromise, not use lawsuits to bully their way through. They have repeatedly shown nothing but contempt and disrespect for the president and his authority.   To them President Obama is acting outside his authority when in fact what they really mean is President Obama isn't giving the GOP their way, and like any spoiled brat, they see that as doing something wrong.  I hope the appeal supports President Obama, I sure support him, and teaches the GOP to use more appropriate methods than filing lawsuits and threatening to shut down Homeland Security to advance whatever concerns they actually have, and teaches the GOP to show some respect for the president and his authority. John Boehner is speaker of the House, he is not the king of America.

While heavily edited photographs have become the norm by casual and professional photographers alike, I think it's incredibly important for photojournalists to consider how heavily processing their images effects their industry. When the raw images citizens take and post on Twitter and Instagram show more "real" pictures of what took place, it makes sense for people to look to these channels for information. Photojournalists have always presented an interpretation of reality by bringing their own perspective on life to the medium, but there needs be a line to what that should be. Their objective should be to inform the public, but this has shifted because heavily processed images tend to grab people's attention and therefore are deemed more successful. In a world where most every photojournalist is a freelancer and pretty images sell, you've got to join the crowd to stay competitive. Everything talked about here is incredibly important to consider, so I'm glad to see this conversation and rules evolve on the years.
Yeah. You pretty much have to post the "doctored" photos side by side with the original versions so we know what you're talking about.

Hi. I'm not a professional photographer or anything... I'm High School student from Brazil. Regardless, I'd like to offer my perspective...
Susan Sontag once wrote that "a photograph can be treated as a narrowly selective transparency". She goes on to say that "In deciding how a picture should look, in preferring one exposure to another, photographers are always imposing standards on their subjects. Although there is a sense in which the camera does indeed capture reality, not just interpret it, photographs are as much an interpretation of the world as paintings and drawings are."
So while I do understand World Press Photo's decision to disqualify submissions that were significantly post-processed, I would argue that the issue at hand is not of capturing what is true, but of having skill. Did the photographer under-expose the shot only to later 'fix' it in a photo-editing program? Did he/she capture a good image or did he/she 'make' a good image?
It's about photography in context. What is the function of journalism, reporting and the press? If it is to get at some semblance of truth,  then photojournalism must follow that impulse.

I wonder why World Press Photo doesn't have an ethical problem with images that are produced by agencies which cover events as a wire service while at the same time functioning as the official photographers for the entities which produce those events. The AP, for example, functions as the official photo supplier of the NFL, while Getty Images serves the same function for FIFA, the IOC, Major League Baseball, the National Hockey League and National Basketball Association. Those relationships pose a very clear conflict of interest, blurring the line between commercial photography and photojournalism.

The Greeks agreed to the original loan terms! This is no different than the huge debt that American students are asked to take on to finance their future. Student debt has severely handicapped an entire generation yet, there is no bridge loan. There is no bankruptcy! Students must pay back their debt or there are sever long-term financial consequences.

Greece is in a difficult position; while it is deeply honourable to defend and decry their current financial woes...their boorish approach does nothing to create a viable solution.
Daniel, Putin's interests - expansion by seizing territory that is part of another sovereign nation, is not legal according to international laws.
